timeline.bodyText: Is there a way to get the average of all requests in stead of the average of all hosts? If host A gets 100 requests and host B gets 10 requests, we probably want (100 * latencyA + 10 * latencyB) / 110 instead of (latencyA + latencyB) / 2. That will be consistent to how to calculate the cluster average
timeline.author: rachelhanhan

replies.bodyText: BTW you can get avgClusterLatency from PartitionStats in PartitionData, we can probably see if we can reuse PartitionStats, because it's also used for metrics emitting purpose
replies.author: rachelhanhan

replies.bodyText:
BTW you can get avgClusterLatency from PartitionStats in PartitionData, we can probably see if we can reuse PartitionStats, because it's also used for metrics emitting purpose

I've thought of using PartitionStats. But it only keeps the cluster level latency/call count/error rate. If I want to find out the call stats for each individual host, I still have to go through the TrackerClient map. So I'm thinking using the call stats from the map directly would produce a more accurate result.
replies.author: rickzx

replies.bodyText: OK I will leave this implementation decision to you, as long as we are using the correct way to calculate avg cluster latency :)
replies.author: rachelhanhan

timeline.bodyText: On a second thought, I started thinking about for the max deviation, we probably care more about the ones that is greater than the average, if a host has 0 latency, it may impact this max absolute deviation. Should we not use absolute?
timeline.author: rachelhanhan

replies.bodyText:
Agreed.
Maybe we could have

Standard Deviation and MeanAbsoluteDeviation to capture the entire variance
MeanSignedDeviation and MaxSignedDeviation to capture the positive outliers
We could also have a metric for (maxLatency - avgLatency) / avgLatency, that directly calculates the max relative health factor.

Please feel free to share your thoughts on this.
replies.author: rickzx

replies.bodyText: Addressed in the new commit. Please see the comment below.
replies.author: rickzx

timeline.bodyText: Is it possible that a host does not get any traffic so the latency is 0, will it be counted here?
timeline.author: rachelhanhan

replies.bodyText: Can we add some unit test on this to cover some different cases?
replies.author: rachelhanhan

replies.bodyText:
Is it possible that a host does not get any traffic so the latency is 0, will it be counted here?

Since I had the orElse(0) clause, it shouldn't be a problem if a host doesn't get any traffic.
replies.author: rickzx

replies.bodyText:
Can we add some unit test on this to cover some different cases?

Sure, I've written some local unit tests. Would you like me to also submit those as official code changes?
replies.author: rickzx

replies.bodyText: I mean for the host that does not have any traffic, we probably don't want to count it in the deviation. For example if we have 5 hosts in total, for some reason 4 of them have avg host latency 30, 32, 32, 34 and the other one does not have any traffic, hence the host latency is 0. When we calculate the deviation, I'm thinking about if we should only use 30, 32, 32, 34 as data points.
replies.author: rachelhanhan

replies.bodyText: Yes it would be great to always have some unit test coverage
replies.author: rachelhanhan

replies.bodyText: Unit tests added in the new commit.
replies.author: rickzx

timeline.message: Remove some absolute deviation monitors. Add new relative factor monitors. Add unit tests
Remove some absolute deviation monitors. Add new relative factor monitors. Add unit tests
Filter out clusters not receving traffic when calculating deviations

timeline.bodyText: Wondering how do you plan to implement this in container? Do you plan to go with multiple percentile relative factors?
timeline.author: rachelhanhan

replies.bodyText: I'm not sure about which percentile to use. I can start by trying out p99, p95. So having a more general interface here might be easier for later experimentations.
replies.author: rickzx

timeline.bodyText: As we discussed offline, I think it's fair to remove mean, since the calculation is a bit more complicated, also it did not provide too much additional value
timeline.author: rachelhanhan

timeline.bodyText: Let's also have a unit test where the call count and latency for some of the hosts are 0.
timeline.author: rachelhanhan

timeline.message: Fix minor rounding issues when calculating cluster average
